Title: Five ways to succeed in sports analytics
Description:
Suggestions or feedback?


    Images for download on the MIT News office website are made available to non-commercial entities, press and the general public under a 
    Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives license.
    You may not alter the images provided, other than to crop them to size. A credit line must be used when reproducing images; if one is not provided 
    below, credit the images to "MIT." 
  














Previous image
Next image















Sports analytics is fueled by fans, and funded by teams. The 19th annual MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference (SSAC), held last Friday and Saturday, showed more clearly than ever how both groups can join forces.

After all, for decades, the industry's main energy source has been fans weary of bad strategies: too much bunting in baseball, too much punting in football, and more. The most enduring analytics icon, Bill James, was a teacher and night watchman until his annual “Baseball Abstract” books began to upend a century of conventional wisdom, in the 1980s. After that, sports analytics became a profession.

Meanwhile, franchise valuations keep rising, women's sports are booming, and U.S. college sports are professionalizing. All of it should create more analytics jobs, as “Moneyball” author Michael Lewis noted during a Friday panel.

“This whole analytics movement is a byproduct of the decisions becoming really expensive decisions,” Lewis said. “It didn't matter if you got it wrong if you were paying someone $50,000 a year. But if you're going to pay them $50 million, you better get it right. So, all of a sudden, someone who can give you a little bit more of an edge in that decision-making has more value.”

Would you like to be a valued sports analytics professional? Here are five ideas, gleaned from MIT's industry-leading event, about how to gain traction in the field.

1. You can jump into this industry.

Bill James, as it happens, was the first speaker on the opening Friday-morning panel at SSAC, held at the Hynes Convention Center in Boston. His theme: the value of everyone's work, since today's amateurs become tomorrow's professionals.

“Time will reveal that the people doing really important work here are not the people sitting on the stages, but the people in the audience,” James said.

This year, that audience had 2,500 attendees, from 44 U.S. states, 42 countries, and over 220 academic institutions, along with dozens of panels, a research paper competition, and thousands of hallway conversations among networking attendees. SSAC was co-founded in 2007 by Daryl Morey SM '00, president of basketball operations for the Philadelphia 76ers, and Jessica Gelman, CEO of KAGR, the Kraft Analytics Group. The first three conferences were held in MIT classrooms.

But even now, sports analytics remains largely a grassroots thing. Why? Because fans can observe sports intensively, without being bound to its conventions, then study it quantitatively.

“The driving thing for a lot of people is they want to take this [analytical] way of thinking and apply it to sports,” soccer journalist Ryan O'Hanlon of ESPN said to MIT News, in one of those hallway conversations.

O'Hanlon's 2022 book, “Net Gains,” chronicles the work of several people who held non-sports jobs, made useful advances in soccer analytics, then jumped into the industry. Soon, the sport may have more landing spots, between the growth of Major League Soccer in the U.S. and women's soccer everywhere. Also, in O'Hanlon's estimation, only three of the 20 clubs in England's Premier League are deeply invested in analytics: Brentford, Brighton, and (league-leading) Liverpool. That could change.

In any case, most of the people who leap from fandom to professional status are willing to examine issues that others take for granted.

“I think it's not being afraid to question the way everyone is doing things,” O'Hanlon added. “Whether that's how a game is played, how we acquire players, how we think about anything. Pretty much anyone who gets to a high level and has impact [in analytics] has asked those questions and found a way to answer some.”

2. Make friends with the video team.

Suppose you love a sport, start analyzing it, produce good work that gets some attention, and — jackpot! — get hired by a pro team to do analytics.

Well, as former NBA player Shane Battier pointed out during a basketball panel at SSAC, you still won't spend any time talking to players about your beloved data. That just isn't how professional teams work, not even stat-savvy ones.

But there is good news: Analysts can still reach coaches and athletes through skilled use of video clips. Most European soccer managers ignore data, but will pay attention to the team's video analysts. Basketball coaches love video. In American football, film study is essential. And technology has made it easier than ever to link data to video clips.

So analysts should become buddies with the video group. Importantly, analytics professionals now grasp this better than ever, something evident at SSAC across sports.

“Video in football [soccer] is the best way to communicate and get on the same page,” said Sarah Rudd, co-founder and CTO of src | ftbl, and a former analyst for Arsenal, at Friday's panel on soccer analytics.

3. Seek opportunities in women's sports analytics.

Have we mentioned that women's sports is booming? The WNBA is expanding, the size of the U.S. transfer market in women's soccer has doubled for three straight years, and you can now find women's college volleyball in a basic cable package.

That growth is starting to fund greater data collection, in the WNBA and elsewhere, a frequent conversation topic at SSAC.

As Jennifer Rizzotti, president of the WNBA's Connecticut Sun, noted of her own playing days in the 1990s: “We didn't have statistics, we didn't have [opponents'] tendencies that were being explained to us. So, when I think of what players have access to now and how far we've come, it's really impressive.” And yet, she added, the amount of data in men's basketball remains well ahead of the women's game: “It gives you an awareness of how far we have to go.”

Some women's sports still lack the cash needed for basic analytics infrastructure. One Friday panelist, LPGA golfer Stacy Lewis, a 13-time winner on tour, noted that the popular ball-tracking analytics system used in men's golf costs $1 million per week, beyond budget for the women's game.

And at a Saturday panel, Gelman said that full data parity between men's and women's sports was not imminent. “Sadly, I think we're years away because we just need more investment into it,” she said.

But there is movement. At one Saturday talk, data developer Charlotte Eisenberg detailed how the website Sports Reference — a key resource of free public data —has been adding play-by-play data for WNBA games. That can help for evaluating individual players, particularly over long time periods, and has long been available for NBA games.

In short, as women's sports grow, their analytics opportunities will, too.

4. Don't be daunted by someone's blurry “eye test.”

A subtle trip-wire in sports analytics, even at SSAC, is the idea that analytics should match the so-called “eye test,” or seemingly intuitive sports observations.

Here's the problem: There is no one “eye test” in any sport, because people's intuitions differ. For some basketball coaches, an unselfish role player stands out. To others, a flashy off-the-dribble shooter passes the eye test, even without a high shooting percentage. That tension would exist even if statistics did not.

Enter analytics, which confirms the high value of efficient shooting (as well as old-school virtues like defense, rebounding, and avoiding turnovers). But in a twist, the definition of a good shot in basketball has famously changed. In 1979-80, the NBA introduced the three-point line; in 1985, teams were taking 3.1 three-pointers per game; now in 2024-25, teams are averaging 37.5 three-pointers per game, with great efficiency. What happened?

“People didn't use [the three-point shot] well at the beginning,” Morey said on a Saturday panel, quipping that “they were too dumb to know that three is greater than two.”

Granted, players weren't used to shooting threes in 1980. But it also took a long time to change intuitions in the sport. Today, analytics shows that a contested three-pointer is a higher-value shot that an open 18-foot two-pointer. That might still run counter to someone's “eye test.”

Incidentally, always following analytically informed coaching might also lead to a more standardized, less interesting game, as Morey and basketball legend Sue Bird suggested at the same panel.

“There's a little bit of instinct that is now removed from the game,” Bird said. Shooting threes makes sense, she concurred, but “You're only focused on the three-point line, and it takes away all the other things.”

5. Think about absolute truths, but solve for current tactics. 

Bill James set the bar high for sports analytics: His breakthrough equation, “runs created,” described how baseball works with almost Newtonian simplicity. Team runs are the product of on-base percentage and slugging percentage, divided by plate appearances. This applies to individual players, too.

But it's almost impossible to replicate that kind of fundamental formula in other sports.

“I think in soccer there's still a ton to learn about how the game works,” O'Hanlon told MIT News. Should a team patiently build possession, play long balls, or press up high? And how do we value players with wildly varying roles?

That sometimes leads to situations where, O'Hanlon notes, “No one really knows the right questions that the data should be asking, because no one really knows the right way to play soccer.”

Happily, the search for underlying truths can also produce some tactical insights. Consider one of the three finalists in the conference's research paper competition, “A Machine Learning Approach to Player Value and Decision Making in Professional Ultimate Frisbee,” by Braden Eberhard, Jacob Miller, and Nathan Sandholtz.

In it, the authors examine playing patterns in ultimate, seeing if teams score more by using a longer string of higher-percentage short-range passes, or by trying longer, high-risk throws. They found that players tend to try higher-percentage passes, although there is some variation, including among star players. That suggests tactical flexibility matters. If the defense is trying to take away short passes, throw long sometimes.

It is a classic sports issue: The right way to play often depends on how your opponent is playing. In the search for ultimate truths, analysts can reveal the usefulness of short-term tactics. That helps team win, which helps analytics types stay employed. But none of this would come to light if analysts weren't digging into the sports they love, searching for answers and trying to let the world know what they find.

“There is nothing happening here that will change your life if you don't follow through on it,” James said. “But there are many things happening here that will change your life if you do.”

Title: Arsenal want Bruno Guimaraes as part of triple summer transfer spree under incoming chief Andrea Berta
Description:
Transfer Centre
                                        


Plus: Arsenal expected to be busy in this summer's transfer market with Andrea Berta poised to oversee their business after agreeing to become sporting director; Crystal Palace open talks with Oliver Glasner over contract extension in attempt to ward off potential interest from RB Leipzig

Thursday 13 March 2025 07:25, UK

The top stories and transfer rumours from Thursday's newspapers...

THE SUN

Arsenal want to sign Bruno Guimaraes as part of a stunning triple summer transfer spree under incoming new chief Andrea Berta.

Premier League owner Tony Bloom has lost £50,000 after betting on his own horse at Cheltenham.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe has declared war on the bloated wage bill at Manchester United.

Newcastle have offered an olive branch to former directors Amanda Staveley and Mehrdad Ghodoussi - as the Toon invited their former chiefs to Wembley on Sunday.

Everton are looking into a shock move for Newcastle midfielder Sean Longstaff, reports claim.


              Download the Sky Sports app
            


              Stream Sky Sports with NOW
            


              Transfer Centre LIVE!
            


              Get Sky Sports on WhatsApp
            

Arsenal are reportedly interested in signing Bayern Munich winger Leroy Sane.

DAILY MIRROR

Arsenal are expected to be busy in the transfer market this summer with Andrea Berta poised to oversee their business after agreeing to become the Gunners' new sporting director.

Trent Alexander-Arnold will miss the Carabao Cup final for the second successive season, but the Liverpool right-back appears to have avoided a serious injury.

Rasmus Hojlund has been given a vote of confidence from the head coach of the Denmark national team.

DAILY EXPRESS

Harry Maguire has been in better form for Manchester United this season, but the Red Devils have been urged to pay off his contract and let him leave the club.

Manchester United are set to lose a second member of their medical team to a Premier League rival.

Tottenham goalkeeper Guglielmo Vicario believes that Andoni Iraola has turned Bournemouth into the best 'pressuring' team around. The Cherries boss is rumoured to be on Spurs' managerial shortlist in case they decide to part ways with current manager Ange Postecoglou.

Formula 1 have announced a major power play by tying down chief executive Stefano Domenicali to a new long-term contract.

THE TIMES

Newcastle United supporters heading back to Tyneside by train after the Carabao Cup final will be barred from drinking alcohol.

Tottenham head coach Ange Postecoglou stands by saying he always wins something in his second year at clubs as Spurs attempt to salvage their season against AZ Alkmaar in the Europa League.

Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player



The rebels calling for the removal of the RFU chief executive, Bill Sweeney, are now attempting to oust the entire board too.

THE TELEGRAPH

Newcastle United are ready to launch "Project 2030" as they move into the second phase of the club's quest for growth under Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund.

THE GUARDIAN

Crystal Palace have opened talks with Oliver Glasner over extending his contract in an attempt to ward off potential interest from RB Leipzig.

Dozens of allegations of misconduct against police officers relating to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster have been upheld by the police standards watchdog, bereaved families have been told.

THE ATHLETIC

Brazilian club Palmeiras and the bodies representing professional clubs in the country have written to FIFA and CONMEBOL demanding action after another high-profile incident of racism in South America.

Atletico Madrid's Angel Correa has been given a five-game La Liga ban after insulting the referee following his red card during Sunday's game at Getafe.

EVENING STANDARD

Levi Colwill says he "caught up on old times" with Thomas Tuchel on the phone, and is hoping the new England manager names him in his first squad on Friday.

DAILY MAIL

Manchester United's £2bn super stadium plans have been thrown into DOUBT as industry insiders call into question Sir Jim Ratcliffe's bold statements. 

Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player



Caoimhin Kelleher is likely to start the Carabao Cup final ahead of No 1 goalkeeper Alisson.

SCOTTISH SUN

Jose Mourinho has told Rangers defeat didn't hurt him as the Fenerbahce boss bullishly claimed 'they're not better than us'.

DAILY RECORD

Steve Clarke could be forced to sweat on the fitness of star man Scott McTominay ahead of the vital Nations League play-off with Greece.

Shanghai Port boss Kevin Muscat has dropped a clue that he is keeping an eye on Rangers - with a nod to Jose Mourinho.

Scottish football chiefs are looking to introduce a new U19 age group in a bid to give more promising youngsters the chance of making the breakthrough.

Title: LIVE UPDATES: IHSA boys' basketball state finals
Description:
Sunny. High 76F. Winds SE at 10 to 15 mph..
                                

Mainly clear. Low 53F. Winds SE at 10 to 15 mph.

 Updated: March 13, 2025 @ 2:35 pm





College/Prep Sports Reporter

The 2025 IHSA boys' basketball state finals at State Farm Center.

Final | 55-35 CougarsEastland pulls away to clinch a spot in the 1A championship against Hope Academy. Parker Krogman with 21 points, and Adam Awender with 17. Gavin Walder and Malachi Persinger with 10 apiece for Peoria Christian.

End 3Q | 44-30 CougarsIt's been the Krogman and Awender show for Eastland, who now have a combined 35 points. PC has been a little more balanced, but it needs a big fourth quarter to keep its state title hopes alive.

Halftime | 30-16 CougarsI may have spoken too soon. Eastland just took off in the second quarter. Adam Awender and Parker Krogman have combined for 21 points and are 8 of 9 from the field.

End 1Q | 13-12 CougarsThis one is a little more competitive early. There was a three-point barrage in the final couple minutes of the quarter. Adam Awender with a quick 9 points for Eastland. Gavin Walder with 8 for PC.

Here's Tyjuan Hunter's buzzer-beater right before halftime https://t.co/3y37xqgHGQ

Final | 56-50 EaglesHope Academy is heading to the state championship game for the first time in program history. Tyjuan Hunter leads the way with 17 points and 10 assists. Brock Fearday with 26 points and 15 rebounds for St. Anthony

End 3Q | 41-25 EaglesSt. Anthony has shown signs of life, but every time the Bulldogs start gaining any kind of momentum, Hope responds. Eagles look poised to get to the 1A state championship.

Halftime | 22-10 EaglesSt. Anthony finally getting some things going offensively, but Tyjuan Hunter just sent the Hope crowd into a frenzy with a full-court, one-handed buzzer-beater.

End 1Q | 7-0 EaglesHope's defense has been relentless. There's just nowhere for St. Anthony to go offensively. As for the Eagles' offense, Tyjuan Hunter looks like a man on a mission. He was on this stage last year, and he scored Hope's first five points today.

My home for the next three days. I'll have updates on the @IHSA_IL boys' 🏀 state finals throughout the weekend for @ngpreps @news_gazette. pic.twitter.com/wkH9AUZZof

Zach Piatt covers high school sports at The News-Gazette. His email is zpiatt@news-gazette.com.

Benet, Evanston, Rich Township and Warren are all trying to win a state championship in Champaign

Title: Report: Texas athletics department admits to NCAA sports betting violations
Description:
Get the best experience and stay connected to your community with our Spectrum News app. Learn More


Get the best experience and stay connected to your community with our Spectrum News app. Learn More


Continue in Browser


Get hyperlocal forecasts, radar and weather alerts.

Please enter a valid zipcode.

Save

AUSTIN, Texas — Between July 11 and Nov. 4, 2024, the Texas athletics department admitted to NCAA violations concerning sports betting, per documents acquired by the Austin American-Statesman.

Although the identities of the five individuals implicated in the violations have been concealed, they encompass two football players, a non-student-athlete affiliated with the women's tennis program, a student assistant and an athletic department employee whose role is unspecified.

The Statesman's reporting found that the five people placed impermissible wagers totaling $14,885.76. The individuals wagered money on athletes' statistics through PrizePicks, a daily fantasy sports site.

Sports betting is illegal in Texas; however, the app PrizePicks is legal.

NCAA rules prohibit student-athletes, coaches and athletics staff from betting on, or providing information that could influence betting on, any NCAA-sponsored sport.

According to Global Sports Advocates, the potential penalties for student athletes betting on NCAA events include:

Title: Rays announce team 'cannot move forward' with new ballpark project in St. Petersburg
Description:
Two weeks before the Tampa Bay Rays begin their 2025 season playing at minor league ballpark Steinbrenner Field, team owner Stuart Sternberg announced on social media that the franchise "cannot move forward" with a new ballpark and development in St. Petersburg, Florida.

"After careful deliberation, we have concluded that we cannot move forward with the new ballpark and development project at this moment," Sternberg wrote in a statement. A series of events beginning in October that no one could have anticipated led to this difficult decision."

"We continue to focus on finding a ballpark solution that serves the best interests of our region, Major League Baseball, and our organization," he continued.

In gratitude for the continued support from our fans and community. pic.twitter.com/vVGHn6nrAA

— Tampa Bay Rays (@RaysBaseball) March 13, 2025

Sternberg added that the city of St. Petersburg is working to restore Tropicana Field, which was significantly damaged during Hurricane Milton, and the team will play there in 2026.

The Rays' announcement comes ahead of a March 31 deadline for the team to put forth $700 million toward a $1.3 billion new ballpark development in the region's Historic Gas Plant District. Construction on the project was to begin over the winter, but Hurricane Milton and disagreement between the team and the St. Petersburg City Council over costs for the development stalled those plans.

[Join or create a Yahoo Fantasy Baseball league for the 2025 MLB season]

In December, the city council voted to approve bonds that would help fund the new ballpark project. The vote, which passed by a 4-3 margin, effectively called the Rays' bluff as the team attempted to back out of the original deal in an effort to restructure its financial obligation.

“We put it out there, we're in. We're a partner in this. Hopefully, the [Pinellas County Board] will follow suit, council member Brandi Gabbard said at the time, via The Athletic.

“And then it will be up to the Rays to decide. It will be up to them to go back to their partners — go back and find other funding. And then when they can't perform, it'll be up to them to come back and say they can't.”

The Pinellas County Board voted the project forward two weeks later, which put the onus on the Rays to come up with their financial obligation toward the ballpark development.

The Rays' announcement was made amid reports that MLB commissioner Rob Manfred and other team owners are pressuring Sternberg to sell the team. The league reportedly wants the franchise to remain in Florida, whether in downtown Tampa or Orlando.

At least two ownership groups have emerged to express interest in buying the franchise, The Athletic reports. One of the groups includes the family of Edward DeBartolo Jr., members of which still have a stake in the San Francisco 49ers, in addition to former New York Yankees minority owner Joe Malloy. In the meantime, Sternberg is attempting to recruit minority investors.

Plans to repair Tropicana Field continue, with St. Petersburg recently approving an additional $950,000 toward a pre-construction phase of the project. Total costs for the city are expected to be $56 million, with the project expected to be completed in January 2026.

The Rays open the 2025 MLB season at Steinbrenner Field on March 28, hosting the Colorado Rockies.

Title: Cooper Flagg injury: Duke prevails over Georgia Tech after freshman star leaves game in wheelchair with ankle injury
Description:
A big second-half performance powered a Cooper Flagg-less Duke past Georgia Tech in Thursday's ACC tournament quarterfinal in Charlotte.

The No. 1 Blue Devils (29-3) found their shooting rhythm in the final 20 minutes after a poor first-half showing en route to a 78-70 win over the Yellow Jackets (17-16).

Duke completed the second-half comeback without the services of Flagg, who left the game late in the first half after injuring his ankle following a rebound.

[Yahoo Fantasy Bracket Mayhem is back: Enter for a shot to win up to $50K]

With the Blue Devils trailing, Flagg grabbed a rebound and landed awkwardly. After spending time on the bench getting treatment, he left for the Duke locker room needing assistance.

Cooper Flagg left the game and was helped to the locker room after suffering an ankle injury against Georgia Tech 😳(via @espn)pic.twitter.com/8Elvj3UoyX

— Yahoo Sports (@YahooSports) March 13, 2025

Flagg was taken for further examination and for X-rays in a wheelchair by medical staff and later ruled "doubtful" to return.

Early in the second half, Flagg exited the Duke locker room not wearing a boot and able to walk on his own. He would find a seat on the Blue Devils' bench where he would watch the remainder of the game.

Cooper Flagg is back up and walking but is ruled out for the rest of the game with an ankle injury. pic.twitter.com/94bgnTHgwy

— ESPN (@espn) March 13, 2025

Duke head coach Jon Scheyer said Flagg suffered an ankle sprain and that X-rays were negative. He did not say when Flagg would play again, only that they will determine his status going forward after they see how bad the swelling gets in his foot.

Flagg recorded only two points on 1-of-7 shooting before his injury.

Duke trailed Georgia Tech 31-26 at the half after missing their first 13 3-point attempts and going 36.7% from the field. That all changed over the final 20 minutes where they outscored the Yellow Jackets 52-39 and finished the game shooting 23.3% from 3-point range and 43.5% from the field.

Duke's Kon Knueppel led all players with 28 points. Khaman Maluach and Isaiah Evans each added 14 points for the Blue Devils.

The 18-year-old Flagg is projected to be the No. 1 pick in June's NBA Draft. In his freshman season with Duke he was named ACC Player of the Year, ACC Rookie of the Year and voted first-team All-ACC and to the ACC All-Defensive and All-Freshman teams.

Duke will next face the winner of Wake Forest and North Carolina in Friday's semifinal.

Title: History-rich Rams back where it all started
Description:
Sunny. High 76F. Winds SE at 10 to 15 mph..
                                

Mainly clear. Low 53F. Winds SE at 10 to 15 mph.

 Updated: March 13, 2025 @ 1:54 pm





Peoria Manual senior Dietrich Richardson is the latest standout to suit up for the Rams. The 6-foot-7, 195-pound guard, who is the nephew of former Illini D.J. Richardson, is a Bradley signee and averaging 18.1 points, 8.3 rebounds and 5.8 assists this winter.

PEORIA — Brandun Hughes and Willie Coleman were among those that took center stage at State Farm Center when Peoria Manual was beginning its boys' basketball dynasty.

That core helped the Rams claim the 1994 Class AA state championship, the first of four straight state titles the program would claim.

While the last two of those championship games were contested at Peoria Civic Center, just 21/2 miles from Manual's campus, Dietrich Richardson and Terrance Paige have helped the Rams back to Champaign this year. For the first time in 30 years.

“Having a chance to represent the community and also having a chance to go out on the main stage and show that all the work that we put in is paying off,” Manual coach Marvin Jordan said. “It's been an end goal for all of us this whole year.”

Manual (23-12), which will face Dyett (25-7) in a Class 2A semifinal game at 3:45 p.m. Thursday, was a mainstay in Champaign in the late stages of coach Dick Van Scyoc's career and the beginning of Wayne McClain's time as Manual's coach.

Van Scyoc's tenure with the Rams ended with their 1994 state title, which followed third-place finishes in 1986 and 1988 and a state runner-up result in 1991. Jordan — who helped Manual to the 2010 2A state title game before playing at Niagara in college — is hoping to lead the Rams to their first state title since 1997. That one capped a four-year run of excellence by Manual.

“I didn't pursue to go and play professionally,” Jordan said. “Once I got back home, I was right back into my high school gym, checking on those guys and making sure they're working out. Because the goal from our community is to get to college.”

So far, so good for Jordan, now in third season as his alma mater's head coach.

“I'm very excited for all of that work to be paying off,” Jordan said. “Guys are able to take a step back and actually look to see that (if) we put the work in, we can make it happen. Being able to understand that is probably the best for me.”

The Rams' ties to Champaign run deep.

McClain — who was an assistant coach at Illinois from 2001-2012 under Bill Self and Bruce Weber and served as Champaign Central's coach during the 2013-14 season — guided the Rams through the final three years of their four-peat. Manual's 1996-97 team finished as USA Today's top team in the country.

The program has produced standout former Illini like Jerry Hester, Sergio McClain, Marcus Griffin, Frank Williams and Da'Monte Williams.

“A lot of alums. It's definitely a tradition,” Jordan said. “Because again, we all learn so much in that gym. If we ever we come back and we're close enough, we're stopping by to visit, regardless if the gym is open. A lot of times we have guys in there working out, but then when the alums come back, the guys are in there are all ears.”

Richardson — a Bradley signee — and Paige have handled the bulk of the offense for the Rams this season, as Richardson averages 18.1 points while Paige contributes 11.4 points per game.

“We have a lot of players who can get their own shots and create shots for others,” Jordan said. “So with having that many of us, I like to keep it an open offense. I like to run, and I'm a big believer in hitting the open guy. Keep it as simple as possible to get the best results.”

The 6-foot-7 Richardson also leads the Rams in rebounds (240) and assists (168), including 18 points, five rebounds and a pair of assists in the team's 52-29 win against Williamsville on Monday night in the Springfield Super-Sectional. A win that clinched Manual's first trip to state since 2019.

“He's been our offensive catalyst,” Jordan said. “He's just been a tremendous leader on both ends of the ball. Having someone like him with leadership to teach a lot of the guys who are younger and have less experience than him, they have a great leader to learn from.”

Reggie Postlewaite, Joshua Humbles and Amare Breedlove round out the remainder of the Rams' starting lineup.

Tony Bradford and Caden Latta have contributed by averaging 8.1 points and 5.3 points off the bench, respectively.

“I don't want to single any one player out,” Jordan said. “As a coach, you don't know if all the guys are going to buy in or how the season is going to go at the beginning. ... This team gets it. They understand. A lot of that was from being a part of the teams in the past and being guys with experience.”

Manual has clicked off nine consecutive wins entering the state tournament, with a Big 12 Conference wins against Danville and playoff wins against Clinton, Tremont, Macomb, Sherrard and Williamsville.

That stretch followed a seven-game losing streak that included a 49-46 loss at Champaign Central at the buzzer on Jan. 31, narrow Big 12 losses to Normal Community and Peoria and a slim setback against Morton.

“We did a lot of learning in that segment,” Jordan said. “In my gym and our program, it's not wins and losses. It's winning and learning. In that time, we did a lot of learning. I feel like each game out there was a different lesson, and I knew that it would help us.”

And the tradition-rich Rams — the only boys' basketball team in IHSA history to win four straight state titles — aren't feeling the heat ahead of their 13th state finals appearance.

“I don't think I would call it pressure at all,” Jordan said. “We've been battle-tested all year, and I think that we've worked hard enough to overcome that. We can hang our hat on the actual work that we've done and not guess and wonder if we would come out and play with the intensity that we want to.”

Still living in Danville more than two decades after retirement, Gene Gourley continues to have an affect on his many former players.

"

Title: Santa Clara scholarship program to help low-income families pay for youth sports
Description:
Santa Clara wants to make it easier for low-income youths to play sports by paying their fees.

Watch NBC Bay Area News 📺 Streaming free 24/7

The Santa Clara City Council voted unanimously Tuesday, with Councilmember Raj Chahal absent, to make the Wade Brummal Scholarship program easier to access and more streamlined. The program helps low-income families pay sports-related fees.

Changes include a streamlined application process for youth sports groups, turning the paper form into an electronic submission, as well as more clear guidelines on the scholarship's uses. Councilmembers also amended the fee application approval process to allow city employees to approve requests up to $2,500. Anything above that amount needs approval from the city's Parks and Recreation Commission.

"My goal is that any kid that wants to play should be able to play, but the kid whose parents can pay, they should be paying a reasonable amount," Councilmember Suds Jain said during the meeting. "That's my philosophy about this."

The city established the scholarship in 2015 and imposes a $25 fee on non-Santa Clara residents participating in local sports groups to provide scholarships for residents who can't afford it. The scholarship has about $235,000 in its fund, according to the city.



Mike Walke, executive board president of the Police Activities League, said the changes make the scholarship program easier to access.

"I'm in favor of the final result, it has clear guidelines and procedures that everybody can follow," Walke told San Jose Spotlight.

Walke and dozens of representatives from other nonprofit youth sports groups met with the city's parks and recreation department multiple times over the course of about a year to discuss the field fees and scholarship program. Walke said while discussions were tense at times, there were efforts on both sides to understand each other's concerns and come to a solution for everyone.

Parks and Recreation Commissioner Vikas Gupta said the program has been underutilized by the city's nonprofit youth sports groups because of the cumbersome application process and general lack of awareness.

"It's kind of hard to project how it's going to play out," Gupta told San Jose Spotlight. "When (nonprofits) have disadvantaged youth in their membership, hopefully they will be able to relay that information to them and share that they in fact are able to support them through the scholarship."

He said the city has a history of prioritizing services to residents, including supporting youth sports, but it can't subsidize the programs fully, so compromises were made.

Last year, the city began charging a $14 per hour fee to use fields. Multiple nonprofit youth sports groups, including the Police Activities League, spoke out against the fees, claiming it was a large financial burden, especially on low-income families who might not be able to afford the increase.

Improving the scholarship is one way the city can ease the burden for low-income families whose children want to play sports. The other is adjusting the field fees, which was approved by parks commissioners Monday.

The proposal includes lowering the amount nonprofit youth sports groups are charged from $14 an hour to $8 an hour. Walke said he would've preferred to not have to pay for fields, as the youth sports groups did before 2024, but added the lower amount is more manageable.

"Zero amount would be wonderful but that's not ever gonna come back, so being realistic," Walke told San Jose Spotlight. "Times are changing, so does everything around you."

The City Council will review the proposed field booking fee updates at a meeting in April.

This report was first published by San Jose Spotlight and provided by Bay City News.

Title: IHSA boys' basketball state tournament: Coaching conversations around the state
Description:
Sunny. High 76F. Winds SE at 10 to 15 mph..
                                

Mainly clear. Low 53F. Winds SE at 10 to 15 mph.

 Updated: March 13, 2025 @ 2:14 pm



































































Sports Editor

With the IHSA boys' basketball state tournament back in Champaign starting with six state semifinal games on Thursday at State Farm Center, we got 21 well-regarded high school coaches from across the state of Illinois to weigh in on the sport they love:

Provided

St. Ignatius boys' basketball coach Matt Monroe.

St. Ignatius boys' basketball coach since 2016 who led the Wolfpack to the Class 3A state tournament in 2022 and 2023, placing third in 2022 and fourth in 2023

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player in Illinois I've ever seen is ... Derrick Rose. Illinois basketball has featured so many incredibly talented and accomplished high school basketball players. Over the years, I have been lucky to have seen, coached and coached against so many amazing players. Some of the best have included Jereme Richmond, Patrick Beverley, Jalen Brunson, Kevin Garnett, E.J. Liddell, Brandon Paul, Jahlil Okafor, Jabari Parker, Phoenix Gill and Jon Scheyer. But if I had to pick one player, I would have to go with Rose. He was an exciting player to watch, led his Simeon teams to multiple state championships and became a cultural icon within the Chicago basketball community.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... the first thing that comes to mind are the IHSA boys' basketball state finals. I went to the state finals with my dad when I was young, and it was an awesome experience being able to coach St. Ignatius in the 3A Final Four the first two years it returned to Champaign.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bruce Weber. I remember watching Lou Henson's Flyin' Illini when I was younger and have some great memories of those awesome teams. I was a student-manager at DePaul University when we hosted the NCAA Sweet 16 the year that Illinois made the championship game. I was in the building working the event during their epic comeback against Arizona and it was one of the greatest games I've ever witnessed live. A few years later, I got to meet Coach Weber a number of times because he was recruiting a couple of players I coached. Even after reaching some incredible heights, he couldn't have been more kind, gracious and humble in all our interactions. That really made a positive impression on me.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... what happens on the day of our games. However, competing against our opponents on game nights is just part of what we do. A lot of time goes into planning practices, watching scout film, meeting with coaches, studying the game, taking care of administrative tasks, monitoring academic progress, mentoring players and more. Those are the unseen hours. While winning is always the goal, and as coaches we put our hearts and souls into doing everything we can to give our teams the best possible chance to be successful on game nights, winning is not the most important part of coaching. The most important aspects of coaching are building lasting, positive relationships with everyone in your program and using basketball to teach important life lessons. At the end of the day, if you keep the main thing the main thing, it will lead to success on the court as well.

Andy Douglas has led the Quincy boys' basketball program during the last 11 seasons after playing for the tradition-rich Blue Devils in the late 1990s.

Quincy boys' basketball coach of 11 seasons and nephew of former Illini great Bruce Douglas has led his alma mater to five regional titles and two sectional titles since 2018

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... I had a front row seat to watch Joey Range play Quentin Richardson in the state championship game in 1998. We just won third place that year and stuck around to watch that game. Those two going back and forth was impressive. It's hard to choose between those two players, so I will go with Range and Richardson. They were men amongst boys and had their way with the competition.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I was not even a year old when my mom and dad took me to my first Illini game. We were there to watch my uncle, Bruce Douglas, play. Derek Harper hit a shot at half-court at the buzzer to win the game. I've been a fan ever since. I love that place and love being able to take my son and family to a game every once in a while.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... when I was young, I had the opportunity to meet coach Lou Henson. He was Illini basketball for years and will always be a staple for the program. As I have grown older, I have an appreciation for Brad Underwood. To be able to do it as long as he has and to adapt with the times is huge.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... this is more than a ‘two hours a day at practice' type of job. The amount of time and energy that gets put in on a daily basis is crazy. There are not too many people out there that would work for less than $6 an hour. At the high school level, we are not coaching for the pay. We genuinely love and care about the kids we coach and want to help teach them life lessons and skills that they can carry on with them when the ball stops bouncing.

Provided

Waukegan boys' basketball coach Ron Ashlaw.

Waukegan boys' basketball coach who coached former Illini Jereme Richmond when Waukegan placed second in Class 4A in 2009 and third in 4A in 2010

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player in Illinois I've ever seen is ... probably Marcus Liberty of Chicago King in the 1980s, followed by Jereme Richmond of our Waukegan Bulldogs during the 2009 and 2010 seasons. My favorite high school player of all-time is Brian Houston of Chicago St. Gregory in the mid-1980s. Toughest warrior I had even seen on the basketball court. He played like he was 6-7 for a player truly 6-3.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I always think of the 1989 Flyin' Illinois Final Four team, the trip to see the state finals with my father when I was a high school player and going to the state finals as a young starting-out freshman coach at Chicago St. Benedict. In those days, we even had a drill called ‘The Road to Champaign' that we utilized frequently in practice. Plus, several trips there to see the Illini during the 2010-11 season.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bruce Weber. He was extremely kind and helpful during my early years at Waukegan, as his program and staff were heavily involved in the life and career of one of our Bulldogs in Jereme Richmond. I always felt that his 2004-05 team ran some of the best pure, true motion offense of any team I have ever seen play, before and since, which is what we have always tried to implement with our teams.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... probably 80 percent of building a season and a team happens outside of the four lines. Building program culture, instilling team standards, managing personalities, gluing parts together, encouraging and motivating over the long road of a season. All of that must be accomplished before the first whistle blows, and the first X's and O's are drawn up.

Provided

Highland boys' basketball coach Deryl Cunningham.

Highland boys' basketball coach who was a Parade All-American at St. Joseph's in 1989 and went on to play in college at DePaul and Kansas State

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player in Illinois I've ever seen is ... Marcus Liberty. He was a 6-foot-8 presence in the 1980s and handled the ball silky smooth like a guard. He was simply before his time.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I think of the Flyin' Illini. It's the way I grew up and watched the games in my high school era.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bill Self. His team had an extra edge. He brought the fire back into the program before moving on to Kansas.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... how much time that really goes into the players and program behind the scenes.

Provided

Glenbrook South boys' basketball coach Phil Ralston when he coached Geneva at the 2015 IHSA boys' basketball state tournament in Peoria.

Glenbrook South boys' basketball coach since 2017 who also led Geneva and Grant. Has more than 400 career wins and guided Geneva to a fourth-place finish in Class 4A in 2015

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... I've seen an awfully lot of really amazing high school players, but Jalen Brunson's performance in the state tournament his junior year in 2014 might have been the most amazing performance I had ever seen in one game. Or maybe Jon Scheyer's 21 points in 75 seconds. I've had two players of mine that scored over 50 points — Nate Navigato at Geneva and Dom Martinelli at Glenbrook South. I might never coach players that put on such amazing performances. I'm still in awe of what I witnessed.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... given that for most of my coaching career, the Civic Center in Peoria served as the site of the the IHSA state tournament, it has a special place in my heart because my Geneva team played there in 2015. However, now that the state finals are at State Farm Center, it is truly one of the best college venues in the country and is perfect for the state finals. Ironically, Glenbrook South's Titan Dome was designed as a mini-replica of the Assembly Hall.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Lou Henson. To me, Illini basketball will always be Coach Henson's teams. I had the opportunity to meet him personally when I was on staff at Northwestern University. There could not have been a more classy person — but that could have been easy given that his teams beat the Wildcats while I was there. I really enjoyed Bruce Weber, too, and his 2005 team might have been one of my favorite Big Ten teams. He's such a tremendous coach, and it was amazing that he made such an amazing impact in such a short period of time at Illinois.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... there is so much more that goes into high school coaching outside of what people see at games. The amount of time that is put in for training, scouting, building relationships and team bonding. Building a successful program often depends on a coach's ability to build a winning culture that often has numerous outsiders who unintentionally are tearing apart what coaches are trying to build. When a coach is able to get his team to stop listening to the outsiders — friends, family, AAU coaches and teammates and people on social media — and only focus on each other, their team's bench and the 84 feet by 50 feet on the court, then something truly magical can occur.

Provided

Rockford Auburn boys' basketball coach Bryan Ott.

Rockford Auburn boys' basketball coach who has won 468 games with the Knights since 1999 and has a third-place finish in Class 4A in 2012 and a fourth-place finish in 4A in 2016

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player in Illinois I've ever seen is ... Derrick Rose. It's an incredibly tough question because there's been so many exciting players over so many years, but Rose won back-to-back state championships at Simeon. A dynamic scorer but also an amazing creator for his teammates. He was unselfish and hard-nosed. Everything you would want from a high school basketball player who just so happened to be a great athlete. It was clear he was headed for the NBA.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I still think of it as Assembly Hall and all the state tournaments I attended as a high school student and then as a young coach. I will never forget my first time watching a game there. I had just finished my junior year of high school, and our team went down to watch the tournament. I was amazed by everyone there: Ben Wilson, Kenny Battle and Kevin Duckworth. But most of all, the lob pass on the baseline out of bounds, over the top of the backboard, to Everette Stephens. Years later, as a high school assistant, watching the defensive efforts of Tai Streets and Thornton versus Farragut and Kevin Garnett. I don't know if Garnett was ever guarded that well in his entire pro career.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... still Lou Henson. Coach Henson resurrected the program, making it nationally relevant once again. Obviously, the Illini had many disappointing finishes in the NCAA tournament in those years. Bob Knight received much attention for his teams' defensive toughness, but I think Illinois under Henson was every bit as tough. From the outside looking in, Coach Henson appeared to be a fair-minded, completely humble individual who was always deflecting praise to this players. The Flyin' Illini remains my favorite collection of players of all-time. All of them from this state and they seemed destined to win the national title.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... I'm not sure anyone who does not hold this position can possibly understand the amount of time a head coach pours into the players and into the craft of coaching itself. The public may see the excitement of game nights and imagine drawing up plays on a marker board, but misses the day-to-day grind of teaching skills, drilling offense and defense and building relationships based on sweat equity. Coaching is not a hobby. Coaching may be paid as a small stipend, and the season may be only four months long, but coaching is truly a year-long endeavor. The head coach essentially has two full-time jobs: whatever career or vocation that pays the bills, and then a coaching position that one better treat as a full-time occupation in order to simply present a competitive product on the floor. No one does this job long if they don't truly love the challenge of developing players and building a team.

Provided

Lemont boys' basketball coach Rick Runaas.

Lemont boys' basketball coach since 2009 who has won more than 250 games and led Lemont to three regional titles since 2022

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Sergio McClain from Peoria Manual. He just seemed like a player who never let his team lose and was able to provide whatever his team needed.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... as a Wisconsin graduate, I think of a lot of frustrating memories of experiencing my team losing to great Illini teams.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Lou Henson. I have fond memories of the way his teams played. The 1988-89 team was ahead of its time, and it's a shame Kendall Gill was hurt for much of that year.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... the time that's spent preparing for practice and games. The scheduling, scouting and film watching take a lot of time.

Provided

Williamsville boys' basketball coach Nick Beard.

Williamsville boys' basketball coach since 2013 who has 253 wins and led the Bullets to a fourth-place finish in Class 2A in 2024

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player in Illinois I've ever seen is ... I had the opportunity to watch Andre Iguodala when he was at Springfield Lanphier. He was a freak athlete who played at a different speed. He was a man amongst boys, a five-tool player who was high flying and defended amongst the best of them.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I think of Dee Brown, Deron Williams and Luther Head. I grew up a die-hard Illini fan.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bill Self. I loved the way he approached the game. I loved his philosophy. I loved his toughness he had about him, but also the way he treated his players.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... the amount of time behind the scenes that coaches who do it right spend. People have no idea until you're in the trenches.

DeKalb boys' basketball coach Mike Reynolds.

DeKalb boys' basketball coach since 2019 has also coached at Galesburg and Bismarck-Henning, compiling more than 450 wins in his career

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player in Illinois I've ever seen is ... Joey Range from Galesburg. I watched him a lot when I was in college. He had the total package of being able to play inside and outside. He played a lot like LeBron James at the high school level. With his size, strength and athleticism, Joey could do everything on a basketball court.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I always think of Andy Kaufmann's shot against Iowa. I remember watching it on TV live and as a Hawkeye fan, I remember being heartbroken. I always think of that shot when I'm inside of Assembly Hall.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bruce Weber. When I was a young coach at Bismarck-Henning and Galesburg, Coach Weber always was willing to share so much with high school coaches. He truly was a developer of talent and men. I always admired how he ran his program, and his teams always felt like family.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... I think the general public fail to realize how close-knit that teams get through the season. We spend so much time with each other, it really becomes like a family. We don't always agree or like each other, but in the end, we all love each other. There isn't much better in life than being part of a team.

DePaul College Prep boys' basketball coach Tom Kleinschmidt, right, and his father, Illinois Basketball Coaches Association Hall of Fame member and former IHSA referee Tom Kleinschmidt Sr.

DePaul Prep boys' basketball coach since 2012 who has led the Rams to consecutive state titles in 2023 and 2024 and has DePaul Prep vying for a third straight state title

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Howard Nathan from Peoria Manual. His combination of speed, skill, basketball IQ, toughness and selflessness was fun to watch. He was a fierce competitor and teammate. He was a pleasure to watch.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... the first thing that comes to mind was watching my father officiate three IHSA state tournaments as a Hall of Fame official. I remember going downstate with him and falling in love with players like Ben Wilson, Ed Horton, Kenny Battle, Levertis Robinson, Steve Bardo, Nick Anderson, Everette Stephens and Marcus Liberty. My first heroes in basketball.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Lou Henson. What talent he had, and to have that many great players and be able to coach them was fun to watch as a teenager.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... that these players are 14-17 year-olds and going through all the things teenagers go through off the court. Although they look like adults, they are young men trying to learn and find themselves while enjoying success and overcoming adversity.

Ron Winemiller with his wife, Whitney, and their two daughters, Maysen and Malone.

Benton boys' basketball coach with 323 wins since 2009 and led the Rangers to a second-place finish in Class 2A in 2024

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Derrick Rose. I got the chance to see him play when I was coaching at Marshall County High School in Kentucky and he and Simeon played in the Marshall County Hoopfest. Holy smokes, he was on another planet from anyone I have ever seen play.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... the IHSA state tournament is the first thing I think of. When they opened those doors and we walked up that tunnel to take the floor last year, it was a view I will never forget.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... this is an easy one for me being a southern Illinois guy: Bruce Weber. I had the chance to get to know him when he was at SIU, and he is just a first-class person who is a great basketball coach.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... the time that goes into preparing for a game, especially a postseason game. The coaches spend countless hours watching film and coming up with a game plan. Sometimes, it doesn't work out, but most people have no idea how much time and effort has gone into preparing for that game.

Provided

Edwardsville boys' basketball coach Dustin Battas.

Edwardsville boys' basketball coach since 2018 who led the Tigers to a 28-3 record this season. The UI graduate was an assistant when Mark Smith won The News-Gazette's All-State Player of the Year in 2017

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... as a coach, Mark Smith from Edwardsville. To be on the bench and his performance in his senior year will be something I will never forget. As a fan of basketball, it is Shaun Livingston.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... growing up an Illini fan and then attending the UI, Assembly Hall has always been a special venue. Now as a high school coach, it's the goal and destination of a great season. My best memory there is watching the Wake Forest game during the 2004-2005 season. It's a special place.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bruce Weber. When he became the Illini coach, I sent him an email as a student at the UI letting him know I was going to go into coaching. I never expected a response, but he sent me a full-page email back letting me know what a great profession it can be and how to impact kids. It was very inspirational.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... what they see on the court on Tuesdays and Fridays is a really small part of what we do. The day-to-day interactions with our players, the program building, fundraising, supporting your coaching staff and the practice planning and decisions that all go into running your own program are endless.

Tom Livatino with his wife, Marie, sons, Luke and Michael, and daughter, Siena.

Loyola boys' basketball coach since 2009 who has won more than 300 games and eight regional titles with the Ramblers

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... I'm biased, but Colin Falls from Loyola is definitely in the picture. He was a 2,000-point scorer who did it all for his high school team from freshman through his senior year before he became the all-time leader in three-pointers made in the Big East when he played at Notre Dame.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... it's the symbol of getting downstate in the best high school basketball tournament in the country. We have a picture of State Farm Center in our locker room and meeting room.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bruce Weber. I really enjoyed watching his teams compete and the 2004-05 Illini team was a great team. Coach Weber was also a very good guy who was easy to talk to.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... it's a non-stop job that has little down time even in the offseason. Coaches families' sacrifice a lot of time, but also benefit from the addition of this extended family that is our team. It's the absolute best job in the world, and we are very fortunate to have it.

Chet Reeder with his wife, Jessica, and their two daughters, Kristen and Kate.

Teutopolis boys' basketball coach since 2018 who led the Wooden Shoes to a third-place finish in Class 2A in 2023 and has five sectional titles in his seven seasons at Teutopolis

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Derrick Rose.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... to me, it is still Assembly Hall. I grew up going to Illini games with my family. A lot of core memories for me in that building. My wife was a cheerleader for the Illini, so I think of her when I hear Assembly Hall. Plus, our third-place finish in 2023 ended on that floor. I love that building.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Brad Underwood. I love his energy and approach to coaching. He coaches players hard and holds them to high expectations.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... all of the time your family dedicates to the program as well. My wife and kids are just as invested in our program as I am.

Brad Tomhave with his family. From left, Cade, Brennan, Brad, McKenzie and Brody.

Pittsfield boys' basketball coach who has won 324 games in charge of the Saukees since 2005 and led Pittsfield to a fourth-place finish in Class 2A in 2011

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Andy Kaufmann because of his uncanny ability to score inside and out. The creativity he was able to play with was special.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I think of the ultimate goal: playing in the state tournament.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Lou Henson. I grew up watching his teams in the 1980s and 1990s. The Flyin' Illini put Illinois basketball back on the map and were an electric team on both ends of the floor. How could you not admire Lou-doo!

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... the amount of time put in outside of practice and game time. It's more than just show up and practice or play. The endless hours scouting and prepping for practice and game is not realized by others. People also don't realize the relationships coaches build with their players on a personal level. You get to know them and see them at their highs and lows. They also get to see you, as a coach, in those moments. Besides the preparations and the competition, that is what I love about being a coach: you get to help grow youngsters into young men and teach them lessons that hopefully will benefit them years after they are graduated.

Matt Laur in the middle, with his family. From left, Carrie, Annabelle, Matt, Grady and Ty.

Pinckneyville boys' basketball coach is 52-12 in his first two seasons coaching the tradition-rich Panthers. He is also McKendree's all-time leading scorer with 2,874 points

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Derrick Rose. He was such a dynamic player on both ends of the floor. He was an incredible scorer from all three levels and had phenomenal court vision as well. What separated him from other great players was his willingness to play defense. He always got after it on the defensive end of the floor utilizing his speed and athleticism to pressure the ball all night.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I think of Illini basketball. I have been to Illini games in every decade since the 1980s. The atmosphere is always amazing.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... I grew up during the Flyin' Illini Lou Henson days, so I will go with Coach Henson.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... how close we are with our players. We spend more time with our teams during the season than we do our own families. My wife and I try and have the team over to the house for meals and fellowship as often as possible. These young men truly are a part of our family.

Provided

Centralia boys' basketball coach Lee Bennett working on gameplans at his home.

Centralia boys' basketball coach since 2007 who has more than 400 wins with the Orphans and reached 700 career wins this season after previous stops at Carlinville, West Pike, Dakota and Alton. His dad, David Bennett, won 527 games with Pittsfield and led the Saukees to a 1990 Class A state title

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I think of going to the games as a boy trying to get down to the B section or even the A section.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Lou Henson. My best buddy from Pittsfield High School went to the UI and was on the Orange Squad for Coach Henson. He would get to dress something like every third home game, and if it was a blowout, would get in for a minute or two. Once Lou came down to put him in the game and said, ‘You see what Kendall Gill is doing, go in and do what Kendall is doing.' Of course, we got quite a kick out of that. Lou was always very gracious to my father and me.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... after the game is over or the bus gets back, you head home and get going on washing all of the uniforms, warmups and bench towels while you work on film from the game and for your next opponent. You are equipment manager, scheduler, trainer, emotions manager and you try to head into the gym for a couple hours with nothing on your mind but helping kids better.

Provided

St. Laurence boys' basketball coach Roshawn Russell.

St. Laurence boys' basketball coach who led the Vikings to a Class 3A sectional title game this season and coached Illini Morez Johnson at St. Rita

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Derrick Rose. I played against him from sixth grade through his senior year of high school. It was always clear he could go to another gear if he wanted to.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I think of Morez Johnson because I coached him and continue to support him, and I also think of winning a state championship with my current team.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Brad Underwood. He is unapologetic about who he is and stands firm in his principles. I respect that, and his success speaks for itself.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... coaching is a full-time occupation as we take on several different roles for our players beyond just being a coach.

Murphysboro boys' basketball coach Daryl Murphy

Murphysboro boys' basketball coach since 1996 has won more than 500 games in charge of the Red Devils and guided them to a second-place finish in Class 2A in 2011

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Marty Simmons. Two-time state champion at Lawrenceville could single-handedly win a game by himself.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I think of the state tournament and my beloved Illini.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bruce Weber. I got to know him at Southern Illinois. He's a fantastic person and a great defensive coach.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... the time you put in. Without question.

Central Catholic's head coach Jason Welch in their IHSA 2A semi-final basketball game at the State Farm Center in Champaign on Thursday, March 9, 2023.

Bloomington Central boys' basketball coach since 2007, with the Philo native winning more than 300 games in charge of the Saints and guiding BCC to a 2014 state championship in Class 2A

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... watching Ronnie Fields and Kevin Garnett when they played with Farragut at a shootout at Danville Area Community College. Those guys were unbelievable. Obviously, I was watching it out of the eyes of a 16-year-old kid, but I was amazed. In terms of coaching, one of the best players I've ever coached against was Ethan Happ at Rockridge, who went on to play at Wisconsin. We held him to like 25 points and 30 rebounds one night, and walked out with a one-point win in a sectional final. He was really, really good.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... the Flyin' Illini come to mind. I grew up in Philo and I had plenty of opportunities to watch them play. I know there's debate on who has had the best team at Illinois, but that was my team,

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Lou Henson. I loved his demeanor, and I knew how much hoops meant to him and his family. Obviously there's been so many good coaches that have opened the doors at Illinois, but I thought it started with him.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... all the behind-the-scenes things, from sweeping the floor, driving the bus and cleaning locker rooms. That said, I love it all. It's a lot of hours, but each one of them I cherish.

Provided

Streator boys' basketball coach Beau Doty

Streator boys' basketball coach has won more than 250 games in charge of the Bulldogs since 2009

➜ The best high school boys' basketball player I've ever seen in Illinois is ... Derrick Rose. Just pure, raw athleticism. Incredible to see in person.

➜ When I hear the words State Farm Center ... I think of attending the state tournament as a kid and watching Kevin Garnett and Ronnie Fields play for Farragut.

➜ The Illini men's basketball coach I've admired the most is ... Bruce Weber. Absolute class act and a great coach.

➜ The one aspect of coaching most people don't realize is ... the amount of mental hours we pour into this job. It is truly a calling, and the bonds you form with your team are really hard to describe or understand from the outside. Coaching consumes you, and it is always in the back of your mind every second of the day on how you, as a coach, can better prepare and serve your team. I wouldn't have it any other way.

Matt Daniels is sports editor at The News-Gazette. His email is mdaniels@news-gazette.com, and you can follow him on Twitter (@mdaniels_NG).

Still living in Danville more than two decades after retirement, Gene Gourley continues to have an affect on his many former players.

"

Title: Cooper Flagg injured in Duke's win over Georgia Tech: College basketball live updates, scores, results
Description:
With Selection Sunday just days away, the Madness is nearly upon us. Men's college basketball conference tournaments are now in full swing and most of the nation's top teams will be in action on Thursday.

The day started with a scary moment in Duke's ACC opener against Georgia Tech. Projected No. 1 NBA Draft pick Cooper Flagg sprained his ankle and needed to be helped off the court just before halftime. The Blue Devils held on for a nervy win, but coach Jon Scheyer was noncommittal on Flagg's status moving forward.

Later on Thursday, two-time defending national champion UConn returns to Madison Square Garden to try to remind everybody why the Huskies are so dangerous in March.

This week may just be a prelude to the Big Dance, but there's a crush of worthwhile action to tune in for in the power conferences and beyond. (Scroll for live updates.)

No. 1 Duke 78, No. 8 Georgia Tech 70No. 4 Wake Forest vs. No. 5 UNC, 2:30 p.m. | ESPN or ESPN2

No. 4 BYU 96, No. 5 Iowa State 92No. 2 Texas Tech vs. No. 7 Baylor, 7 p.m. | ESPN/ESPN2 No. 3 Arizona vs. No. 6 Kansas, 9:30 p.m. | ESPN/ESPN2

No. 8 Ole Miss 83, No. 9 Arkansas 80No. 5 Texas A&M vs. No. 13 Texas, 3:30 p.m. | SEC Network No. 6 Kentucky vs. No. 14 Oklahoma, 9:30 p.m. | SEC Network

No. 4 Xavier vs. No. 5 Marquette, 2:30 p.m. | Peacock No. 3 UConn vs. No. 6 Villanova, 9:30 p.m. | FS1

No. 8 Oregon 72, No. 9 Indiana 59No. 5 Wisconsin vs. No. 13 Northwestern, 2:30 p.m. | Big Ten Network

Boise State vs. San Diego State, 5:30 p.m. ET | CBSSUNLV at Utah State, 11:30 p.m. ET | CBSS

The Hogs fought valiantly to get back into their second-round game against the Rebels, but they ultimately came up short after two missed free throws in the waning seconds and then the 3-pointer by Pedulla.

Coach Cal's team will have a nervous few days as the Hogs are firmly on the NCAA tournament bubble.

The Rebels got a rebound on a missed free throw with 7.9 seconds left in a tie game and guard Sean Pedulla drilled the game-winning 3:

SEAN PEDULLA WINS IT FOR OLE MISS! pic.twitter.com/wqXYP36OiG

— Mr Matthew CFB (@MrMatthew_CFB) March 13, 2025

Duke head coach Jon Scheyer said Flagg suffered an ankle sprain and that X-rays were negative. He did not say when Flagg would play again, only that they will determine his status going forward after they see how bad the swelling gets in his foot.

More on Flagg's injury right here

The Cougars' torrid run continues. That's their ninth consecutive win and advances them to the Big 12 semifinals, where they'll play the winner of Colorado vs. Houston.

Meanwhile, we have a shootout between Iowa State and BYU. The Cyclones are projected to be a No. 3 seed in the NCAA tournament while the Cougars are likely looking at a No. 5 seed.

The Red Storm are as hot as any team in the country as we near March Madness. They've only lost one game in 2025 and rolled right through Butler in their Big East tournament opener.

St. John's is playing at a high level, just rolled past Butler by 21, 78-57 at first round of Big East tournament. Big East POY Rj Luis gets 20 and lock down defense paves the way.

— Dick Weiss (@HoopsWeiss) March 13, 2025

Per John Ewing of BetMGM, Duke was the most-bet team on Thursday as a 23.5-point favorite. The Blue Devils won by eight after Cooper Flagg's first-half injury.

.@DukeMBB -23.5 was the most bet (money) team to cover on Thursday at @BetMGM Cooper Flagg got hurt ❌Duke won by 8 🤮 pic.twitter.com/LwpXGdp74P

— John Ewing (@johnewing) March 13, 2025

The Blue Devils got more than they bargained for in their ACC tournament opener, but they survived and will face the winner of Wake Forest-North Carolina on Friday.

The bigger question is the severity of Cooper Flagg's ankle injury and how long he'll be out.

As Duke-GT winds down, here's a look at other notable live games ongoing:St. John's 74, Butler 51Oregon 61, Indiana 54Iowa State 68, BYU 61Ole Miss 42, Arkansas 34

The Blue Devils are firing on all cylinders now. After an alley-oop from Kon Knueppel to Khaman Maluach, Isaiah Evans drilled a 3-pointer to push Duke's lead to double digits.

MAN MAN 🙆‍♂️🙆‍♂️🙆‍♂️🙆‍♂️🙆‍♂️🙆‍♂️🙆‍♂️🙆‍♂️🙆‍♂️ pic.twitter.com/EPD5X795KM

— Duke Men's Basketball (@DukeMBB) March 13, 2025

The Yellow Jackets stopped the bleeding and are still hanging in there after Duke's blitz out of the break.

The Blue Devils are shooting the ball much better in the second half after missing their first 13 3-point attempts and going 36.7% from the field in the opening 20 minutes.

Meanwhile, in on-court action, the Blue Devils scored the first 12 points out of the locker room and have taken the lead early in the second half. Kon Knueppel and Sion James hit 3s as Duke is finally finding the mark from deep.

That's one way to respond after losing your star player.

Cooper Flagg has emerged from the Hornets X-ray room, still in a wheelchair. His left ankle is heavily swollen.

— Bryan Fischer (@BryanDFischer) March 13, 2025

Injury updates: Maliq Brown (left shoulder) - outCooper Flagg (left ankle) - doubtful to return

— Duke Men's Basketball (@DukeMBB) March 13, 2025

The ESPN broadcast is now showing Cooper Flagg off his feet, being wheeled in a wheelchair to get examined:

OH NO. They got Cooper Flagg in a wheelchair 😱pic.twitter.com/j5ZCHwRXFA

— BetMGM 🦁 (@BetMGM) March 13, 2025

The Blue Devils cut into the GT lead late in the half, but the bigger concern is the health of Cooper Flagg. He had to be helped into the locker room just before the break.

UPDATE: Cooper Flagg needed to be helped to the locker room. He could not put any pressure on his left leg. pic.twitter.com/oE73CmAbUf

— Miles Jordan (@Miles_Jordan_) March 13, 2025

Flagg headed to the Duke bench after he blocked Duncan Powell's layup attempt late in the first half.

After Flagg denied Powell at the rim, the Blue Devils transitioned up court and Isaiah Evans nailed Duke's first three-pointer of the game.

Flagg would need assistance as he headed back to Duke's locker room with the first half coming to a close.

OH NO.. pic.twitter.com/deu3lhIxEO

— Eye On College Basketball Podcast (@EyeOnCBBPodcast) March 13, 2025

With 3:56 left in the first half, Georgia Tech is up 26-12 and Duke's poor shooting is the story.

The Blue Devils are 26% from the field and 0-for-13 from 3-point range. Cooper Flagg has just two points on 1-of-3 shooting.

Georgia Tech's Baye Ndongo and Duncan Powell lead all players with nine points.

❌ RETURN TO SENDER ❌My goodness Baye Ndongo 😱 📺 @GTMBB x ESPN pic.twitter.com/at5Ei7Jgyu

— ACC Men's Basketball (@accmbb) March 13, 2025

Lance Terry THROW DOWN! 💪Jackets are BUZZING, lead by 11 with 7:38 left in the first half.📺 @GTMBB x ESPN pic.twitter.com/zTm8MfQvyd

— ACC Men's Basketball (@accmbb) March 13, 2025

The Red Storm have stormed out to an 18-3 lead against the Bulldogs through the opening eight minutes.

RJ Luis leads all players with 8 points, while Kadary Richmond, who recorded the program's first triple-double since 1999 over the weekend, has 5 points.
